content:
Rare Disease Diagnosis: Whole Genome Analysis

What This Analysis Does

This analysis searches your patient's entire genome to find genetic variants that could be causing their rare disease. Unlike targeted tests that look at specific genes, whole genome sequencing examines all 3 billion letters of DNA to identify disease-causing mutations. This comprehensive approach is particularly powerful for undiagnosed genetic conditions where the causative gene is unknown.

The analysis detects multiple types of genetic changes: single letter changes (SNVs), small insertions/deletions (indels), large structural rearrangements (SVs), and changes in gene copy numbers (CNVs). Each variant is annotated with information about its potential to cause disease, helping clinicians prioritize which genetic changes to investigate further.

When To Use This

  • Undiagnosed Genetic Disease: Patient with clinical features suggesting a genetic condition but no diagnosis after standard testing
  • Complex Phenotypes: Multi-system disorders that don't fit a single gene or known syndrome
  • Negative Panel Testing: Previous gene panels or exome sequencing failed to identify a cause
  • Comprehensive Variant Detection: Need to detect all variant types including structural variants and CNVs
  • Research and Gene Discovery: Investigating novel disease genes or mechanisms
  • Precision Medicine: Identifying actionable variants for targeted therapies

What You Need

1. Whole Genome Sequencing Data (FASTQ Files)

You need paired-end Illumina sequencing files from your patient's DNA sample:

  • Sample source: Blood, saliva, or tissue DNA from patient (and optionally parents for trio analysis)
  • File format: Paired FASTQ files (typically *_R1.fastq.gz and *_R2.fastq.gz)
  • Sequencing depth: Minimum 30x coverage recommended, 40-50x optimal for clinical diagnosis
  • Read length: 150bp paired-end reads (standard Illumina)
  • Platform: Illumina HiSeq, NovaSeq, or equivalent

2. Sample Information Sheet (CSV File)

Create a CSV file describing your samples with this exact format:

sample,lane,fastq_1,fastq_2,sex,phenotype,paternal_id,maternal_id,case_id
patient01,L001,patient_R1.fastq.gz,patient_R2.fastq.gz,2,2,,,case001

Column Details:

  • sample: Unique identifier for this sample (e.g., patient ID or sample name)
  • lane: Sequencing lane identifier (usually L001, L002, etc. - found in your FASTQ filenames between _S1_ and _R1_)
  • fastq_1: Path to Read 1 file (forward reads, *_R1.fastq.gz or *_1.fastq.gz)
  • fastq_2: Path to Read 2 file (reverse reads, *_R2.fastq.gz or *_2.fastq.gz)
  • sex: Patient biological sex - use 1 for male, 2 for female, 0 for unknown or ambiguous
  • phenotype: Disease status - use 2 for affected (has disease), 1 for unaffected, 0 for unknown
  • paternal_id: If analyzing a trio (patient + parents), enter the father's sample ID here. Leave empty for single patient analysis.
  • maternal_id: If analyzing a trio, enter the mother's sample ID here. Leave empty for single patient analysis.
  • case_id: Identifier for this case (can be same as sample name for single patients, or family ID for trios)

Example for Single Patient:

sample,lane,fastq_1,fastq_2,sex,phenotype,paternal_id,maternal_id,case_id
patient01,L001,patient_R1.fastq.gz,patient_R2.fastq.gz,2,2,,,case001

Example for Trio (Patient + Parents):

sample,lane,fastq_1,fastq_2,sex,phenotype,paternal_id,maternal_id,case_id
patient01,L001,patient_R1.fastq.gz,patient_R2.fastq.gz,2,2,father01,mother01,family001
father01,L001,father_R1.fastq.gz,father_R2.fastq.gz,1,1,,,family001
mother01,L001,mother_R1.fastq.gz,mother_R2.fastq.gz,2,1,,,family001

How to find lane information: Look at your FASTQ filenames - the lane is typically shown as L001, L002, etc. For example, in the filename sample_S1_L001_R1_001.fastq.gz, the lane is L001.

3. Reference Genome

Choose the human genome version matching your clinical requirements:

  • New studies: GRCh38/hg38 (recommended - latest reference with improved accuracy)
  • Legacy compatibility: GRCh37/hg19 (use if comparing to older clinical databases or previous analyses)

What You'll Get

Variant Calls and Annotations

  • Single Nucleotide Variants (SNVs): Individual DNA letter changes that may alter protein function
  • Small Insertions and Deletions (Indels): Short additions or removals of DNA sequence
  • Structural Variants (SVs): Large genomic rearrangements including deletions, duplications, inversions, and translocations
  • Copy Number Variants (CNVs): Regions with abnormal gene copy numbers (losses or gains)
  • Ranked Variants: Variants prioritized by likelihood of causing disease
  • Gene Annotations: Which genes are affected and how (loss of function, missense, etc.)
  • Pathogenicity Scores: CADD scores predicting if variants are likely harmful
  • Clinical Relevance: Links to known disease-gene associations from medical databases

Quality Control Reports

  • Coverage Analysis: How well each region of the genome was sequenced (identifies gaps)
  • Sequencing Quality Metrics: Read quality, alignment rates, duplicate levels
  • Sample QC: Verification of sample identity and quality
  • MultiQC Report: Comprehensive HTML report with all quality metrics and visualizations

Analysis-Ready Outputs

  • VCF Files: Standard variant call format files with all detected variants
  • Annotated Variants: Variants with functional predictions and clinical annotations
  • BAM Files: Aligned sequencing reads for visualization in genome browsers
  • Ranked Candidate Lists: Top candidate disease-causing variants for clinical review

Expected Analysis Time

  • Single patient (30x WGS): 12-18 hours
  • Single patient (50x WGS): 18-24 hours
  • Trio analysis (3 samples): 24-36 hours
  • Multiple unrelated patients: Scales approximately linearly with sample count

Note: Analysis time depends on data size, coverage depth, and computational resources. The pipeline processes samples in parallel when possible to optimize runtime.

Scientific Background

This analysis uses the nf-core/raredisease pipeline, a best-practice workflow developed from clinical diagnostic experience analyzing thousands of rare disease patients. The pipeline uses DeepVariant, an AI-based variant caller developed by Google that achieves high accuracy through deep learning. Structural variants are detected with Manta, and variants are annotated using the Variant Effect Predictor (VEP) with CADD pathogenicity scores. This combination of tools represents current best practices in clinical rare disease diagnostics and has demonstrated ~40% diagnostic yield in production healthcare settings.

The pipeline follows the workflow used in the Stockholm region of Sweden for clinical diagnostics, analyzing nearly 3,000 whole genomes and 1,000 exomes annually. It implements quality control standards appropriate for clinical use and provides ranked variant outputs optimized for clinical interpretation.

Clinical Considerations

Diagnostic Yield: Whole genome sequencing achieves approximately 40% diagnostic rate for rare genetic diseases in clinical practice. Success is highest when:

  • Clinical phenotype is well-characterized
  • Disease has a genetic basis (familial clustering or known genetic causes)
  • High quality, high coverage sequencing data is available
  • Parental samples available for inheritance pattern analysis (trio analysis)

Interpretation: Results should be interpreted by qualified clinical geneticists or genetic counselors in the context of the patient's clinical presentation. Not all detected variants are disease-causing, and clinical correlation is essential.

Incidental Findings: Genome-wide analysis may identify medically actionable variants unrelated to the primary indication. Consider institutional policies for reporting secondary findings.

Data Requirements and Costs

Sequencing Requirements:

  • WGS generates approximately 100-150 GB of raw data per sample at 30x coverage
  • Higher coverage (50x) produces proportionally more data but improves variant detection sensitivity
  • Ensure adequate storage for both raw FASTQ files and analysis outputs

Computational Resources:

  • Analysis requires substantial computational resources (64+ CPU cores, 360+ GB RAM)
  • Default node size: XSMALL (suitable for test data)
  • Recommended for production: LARGE or XLARGE for optimal performance

Getting Started

Step 1: Ensure your whole genome sequencing data meets quality standards (30x+ coverage, Q30+ quality scores)

Step 2: Create your samplesheet CSV file with sample information, following the format above exactly

Step 3: Upload your FASTQ files and samplesheet to Camber stash storage

Step 4: Run this analysis, providing your samplesheet and choosing the appropriate reference genome

Step 5: Review the MultiQC report first to verify data quality, then examine ranked variant lists

Step 6: Work with clinical genetics team to interpret candidate variants in clinical context

Advanced users: See full pipeline documentation
command: nextflow run nf-core/raredisease --input ${input} --outdir ${outdir} --analysis_type wgs --variant_caller deepvariant -profile test -r 2.6.0
